content.body: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/52065 I am prototyping `using` declaration support with `AsyncLocalStorage`. In order to address unexpected declaration without `using`, a leakage check is performed when a task (AsyncResource) callback is finished. If there is any active disposable async local storage value, an error is emitted to hint such misuse.

content.body: This could help in less refactoring when adding async context support, i.e. no need to create a new function/arrow function for sub-operations and avoid violating TCP when mutating async context values, as rbuckton suggested.
what happens if you have `AsyncLocalStorageDisposableStore`s created and disposed of in a non-stacked way?
content.formatted_body: what happens if you have AsyncLocalStorageDisposableStores created and disposed of in a non-stacked way?

content.body: At the moment, it restores the bound `AsyncLocalStorage` value to the one when it was created. However, I think it could avoid restoring the value if the bound `AsyncLocalStorage` was changed so that it could produce fewer conflicts.
